sp.p: I'm confident was he; and I've no doubt I shall be the next one he'll want to put out of the way, in spite of all his gammon about my integrity. The purse he gave me— (takes purse from pocket) here it is. I'm very fond of lucre, but its very touch is fire. (throws purse on ground)

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Then Gilbert was right—I am lost. Let us fly! (they rush to the door) Silence!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: He's coming back.

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Heaven protect me!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: No chance of the door—I'll try the window. (looks out at window) Fifty feet at least, that's no go.
sp.stage: Music — Hides on balcony , R.
Enter Ruthven, with candelabra, C.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: You see I have soon returned, dear Helene. Your brother was asleep, and I would not disturb him. (looking at her) How pale you are !

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: (looking fixedly at him) Yet not so pale as you, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Dearest, I never had much colour, through the quantity of blood I lost by the wound I received from your brother.

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: But your pallor, George, appears more like that of a corpse than a human being.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: What mean you, Helene ?

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: I can hardly say, but for the first time you seem to inspire me with a secret dread.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Why do you tremble—give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Yours has the icy grasp of death !

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Speak not thus, my dear wife! Let this fond embrace reassure you.

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Touch me not, for Heaven's sake! It seems to me as if the grasp of death was on me.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Helene, who has been here during my absence ?

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: No one—no one!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: (looking around) Who could it have been ? (kicks against purse which he picks up) The purse I gave Lazare ! The wretch ! he has been here and revealed all!

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: (shrinking from him) It is, then, true.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Not a moment then is to be lost?
sp.stage: (Music — closes the C. door.

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Why do you close the door ? (trembling)

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Are we not united for ever—are you not my bride?

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, my lord— (he takes her hand) Oh, my brother, Gilbert.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: (on the balcony) Help—help !

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: We were not alone, then ?

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Save me—save me! Help—help!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Your cries are useless—you are Ruthven's bride.
sp.stage: (takes her up in his arms.

sp.speaker: Helene.
sp.p: Help—help!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: 'Tis too late—none can tear you from my grasp.
sp.stage: Music — Rushes off through door with her, L.
Lazare rushes from balcony, and goes to the door, C., which he finds locked — He calls, " Help—help! "

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (without, shaking the door) I am here to save you —open the door!

div.stage: Lazare opens the door —Gilbert rushes on, c.— he is without his coat.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: He had me bound, but I burst my bonds—I darted past the four men who tried to hold me back. My unknown friend, the gipsey, again warned me of my sister's danger. Where is Helene ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: (pointing to door, L.) There, with—oh !
sp.stage: (shuddering — a piercing scream is heard — Music.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (with a wild cry) Heaven have mercy on her.

div.stage: He rushes to the door, L., and meets Ruthven coming from it — Ruthven starts on seeing Gilbert, who seizes him by the throat — a mortal struggle ensues, in which they approach the window — Music.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: (struggling) Both of us will perish, so be it then.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (struggling) Willingly, so that I destroy the fiend. (they struggle again —Ruthven is about to throw Gilbert out of the window —Gilbert regains his feet, and precipitates Ruthven out of the window — he then rushes to the door, L.)

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Oh, Helene, my dear sister! Goes off L. door.

div.stage: (Lazare seizes pieces of furniture, which he throws out of the window, one after the other)

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: This time I'll do for him, and no mistake.

div.stage: (closed in by

div.head: Scene Second.— A Corridor in the Castle.—(1st Grooves.)
div.stage: Enter Guillaume, Tenantry, and Servants, R.— they all seem alarmed.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of the noise, and that piercing scream which came from the bridal chamber, ringing through the whole castle !

div.stage: A Servant and Three Others enter, hastily, L.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Monsieur Gilbert has escaped from his keepers, and burst his chains.
sp.stage: Enter Gilbert, haggard, R.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Dead! I was too late! (the Servants advance towards him) Touch me not, on your life. Run, Guillaume, to your mistress's chamber, and you will see a sorry sight. (to Servant) Get a torch instantly. Rushes out, L.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What can have happened?

div.stage: Enter Lazare, R.— he is pale, and his hair standing erect.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Lazare! what does all this mean ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: (hardly knowing what he says) Murder! robbery! resuscitation! extermination!
sp.stage: Rushes off after Gilbert, L.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Follow me, my friends, to Ma'amselle Helene's apartment. Heaven grant that my fears may prove unfounded !

div.stage: (Music — They follow Guillaume off, R.— the scene changes to

div.head: Scene third.
div.stage: — A Precipice by the Side of the Castle of Tiffanges. On the R. the high turret.
The mangled corpse of Ruthven at the foot of turret, with all the pieces of furniture round it. Midnight strikes — the moon is seen rising.
Gilbert, with a torch in his hand, is seen coming down the rocks out of the flies, followed by Lazare, seeking for the body of Ruthven— after some difficulty they find it.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: I could but avenge you, Helene!
sp.stage: (Lazare, pushing a large piece of rock, which seems to fall over the body of Ruthven, and crush it)

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: This time I will inherit, and no mistake !

div.head: Scene first.
div.stage: —A Boudoir, Looking on to a Terrace, with a View of the Bay of Naples. Prie Dieu, L. U. E.

Antonia is seen seated on the terrace, R., looking towards the sea, C.—Lazare, looking through a telescope, L.—Ziska (the Unknown) dressed as an Arab slave, standing behind, and gazing steadfastly at Antonia.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: There, ma'amselle, the passengers are landing from the vessel we first saw but as a speck on the horizon this morning, and the other is standing for the harbour. I'd lay something handsome that Monsieur Gilbert is in one of them.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: (rising) His letter said he would arrive to-day.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: (up stage) Then, doubtless, he will not fail to keep his word.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p:
You're right there, Ziska, for if you knew Count Gilbert, you'd know he never fails when he has given
his word, and sometimes to his cost too, for if he had once broken his word with a certain individual in Spain, months ago, he would have been now a far happier man!

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: (coming forward) Ever faithful, my good Lazare. I shall not forget to mention to Gilbert on his arrival, how I am indebted to you for the comfortable abode I found ready for me here!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Lor, ma'amselle, I had very little to do with it. If any thanks are due it is to Ziska yonder, who merits them all.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: (to Ziska) How can I ever sufficiently reward you for your tried attachment to me ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I seek not for thanks—I have but followed the dictates of my heart. Slightly inclines her head, and exit, L.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: What a strange being!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: And what eyes! there's no mistake about them! I'm sure I've seen those eyes somewhere before !

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: But how did you first meet her ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Why, you see, ma'amselle, Monsieur Gilbert said to me, "Lazare, my friend," for since I have inherited, we are on terms of great intimacy. " Lazare, my friend, start instantly for Naples, and prepare a suitable abode to receive my dear affianced bride, according, therefore, for Naples I started, and on arriving here I saw this little villa, situated on a rock, overlooking the bay, which I thought was just the thing, and, therefore I settled on it at once—this done, Ziska suddenly appeared, and informed me she had served the former tenants; liking her appearance, and thinking she'd form a very good companion for me to have a sentimental walk with by the seaside in a summer evening, I instantly engaged her, and she has turned out a first rate acquisition.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Indeed she has—she anticipates my slightest wishes. But why did Gilbert entreat me to leave France, and come here ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Doubtless he has some private reason.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: I can fully understand, that after the sudden death of his dearly beloved sister, France should have become hateful to him—but why not let me return to Spain, my native country, instead of coming to Italy, where I have neither friends nor relations.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Why ? why, because it's in Spain where we first met him.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Well, then, England ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: No, that's where he comes from.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Of whom are you speaking, Lazare?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Why, of Monsieur Gilbert's mortal enemy.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Has Gilbert an enemy ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: And such an one too! And so should I have, if he came back again—for I've spent nearly half my inheritance.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: What do you mean by—If he came back again ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Why, he's already been back once, although my lord Gilbert killed him quite as well the first time as he did the second.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Gilbert take the life of a fellow being!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: But he wasn't a fellow being, so that makes all the difference. But I was wrong to mention the matter to you at all, so please ma'amselle, never let out the name of Ruthven to Monsieur Gilbert, if you don't hear it first from him.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Ruthven!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: That's how he was called. (shuddering) Oh, oh ! the very thought of him gives me a cold shudder—but I'll leave you now, ma'amselle, and go and see after a little business of my own. I don't mind letting you into the secret—it's a slight love affair, a young female for whom I have a great predilection, and as Count Gilbert is about to enter the state of holy connubiality, I've a great mind to follow his example. Men were sent on earth to fulfil a mission, and I think it's high time that I should set about mine, and take a wife to help me in it.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: I hope she you choose may prove worthy of you.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Thank you, ma'amselle—I've no doubt she will, for I intend to well look before I leap. Besides, I flatter myself of being a fair physiognomist, and a perfect judge of the opposite sex. Well, I sincerely hope to see Count Gilbert back soon, and with an object, the loss of which seems to prey so heavily upon his mind.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: What object do you allude to ?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Why, a certain amulet that had been in the family for years, which poor Ma'amselle Helene had on the night of his death, and which disappeared in a most mysterious way, and was never since heard of, although Monsieur Gilbert has offered fabulous sums for its recovery. But time fleets on, and my dear little Fenella will be waiting for me. (crossing to R.) Cupid calls, and as a weak mortal, I obey. Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
(taking out a letter, and reading it) " Dear Antonia—if you bear the love for me I think you do, I entreat you leave France—do not return to your father at Cadiz, but start instantly for Naples, where you will find Lazare, and everything prepared for your reception. An omen of ill has again crossed my wretched path of life—should you not yield to my entreaties, you yourself might fall a victim to him who seems to crush all around that are dear to me. On the 15th of
March I shall again press you to my heart." This is the 15th of March—my heart tells me he will not fail. (Music) Heaven grant that he may have already landed, for yonder dark clouds announce a comming tempest.

div.stage: (Music — She goes and kneels at the Prie Dieu — suddenly the door opens, and Gilbert rushes on, R.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Dear Antonia!

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: (rushes into his arms) Heaven did not hear my prayers in vain!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Thanks, my dear affianced bride, for yielding to my entreaties.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Did you for a moment doubt I should ? But why all these measures?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: After the death of my dear Helene, you know I left France, and passed nine months with you at Cadiz ; having gained your parents' consent to our union, I returned to Brittany, to prepare the home of my ancestors for the reception of my future bride; having arrived there, I determined to pass a night in the chamber where I had been once warned of danger threatening those dear to me. Heaven must have given me inspiration, for again a vision appeared, warning me that the fiend followed my steps, and but sought the opportunity of discovering the idol of my heart to destroy it. I then instantly wrote, begging you not to come to Tiffanges, but instantly proceed to Naples, and now I have you in these arms, I will lose not a moment in calling you mine, and this very night all is prepared for me to lead you to the altar.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: To be united to part no more. (distant thunder — goes up to C. window) See what a storm is rising—look at yonder vessel striving to gain the harbour.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (R., down stage) The very one that left France when we set set sail, and has performed the voyage with us.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: I thank Heaven that you are out of the reach of all danger.
sp.stage: Enter Ziska, L.
sp.p: Ah, Ziska, my faithful friend ! I know you will be rejoiced to hear my approaching happiness.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Who is that female ? (recognizing the Unknown) Heaven!

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: A faithful attendant, who has zealously served me since my arrival here.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (R.) I surely know those features!

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.stage: Exit, R.
sp.p: Doubtless such a traveller as you have been may have met her before. However, I'll leave you for a short time, so you may converse together about the scenery of her native Africa.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Why leave me, dear Antonia ?

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: The bride of Gilbert requires another dress than this for her wedding garb. I shall not keep you long waiting ; a plain wreath is all I require—for the brightest gem I bring Gilbert is the purity of the love I bear him.
sp.stage: Music — She crosses to L. D., and exit.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (to Ziska) You are pale—you tremble !

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: (C.) I do.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Why cast that menacing look at Antonia—it did not escape me ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I hate her.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: We have met before, have we not? —but where?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Ingrate.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: I now remember—you bear the features of the old Breton that saved my life, and who warned me of the fate of my poor sister.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I am glad to see you do not forget me!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: What being are you who can thus change form and visage at your pleasure ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Would that I could change my heart too!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Why thus follow my steps ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Can you not guess ?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I love you, Gilbert.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (R.) Love me!

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Has your heart no answer to me for those words ?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: None—your manner makes me tremble.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: And that is your only reply to me who has watched over you like a guardian spirit, and done all that a loving heart could do!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Yet you did not save my sister.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I dared not—I would have saved her had it been in my power. Look at me, Gilbert, and read from the depths of your heart if you could not love me!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: How can you ask, when you know I am betrothed to Antonia ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Gilbert, I am immortal, but for your love would willingly sacrifice all—cast me not from you.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p:
(crosses to L. corner) Woman, I cannot love you
seek some other heart that is free, and do not attempt to cast a cloud over my happiness.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Your happiness is but a dream—beware, lest I should wake you from it. (storm gets louder.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (L.) Woman, or what thou art, I defy you.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Indeed! then you have sealed her fate. Farewell! you will remember me when I am no longer here to shield those you hold dear. Gilbert, your dream of happiness is at an end—let destiny take its course. Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: What dreadful words are those? Antonia! Antonia! (storm rages very loud) The elements seem combined to announce some dreadful danger near at hand. Antonia ! I will seek her, and she shall not leave for an instant. Music — Exit, L.

div.stage: Enter Lazare and several Fishermen, R.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: (R.) The vessel has struck on the rocks, and is going to pieces. Run, friends, and see if we can't save some of the poor devils on board—put out to sea, distinguish yourselves, and I'll stop here and report your valiant conduct, should you be drowned—for if we all shared the same fate, no one would be left behind to tell the tale. Exit Fishermen, R.

What a noble sentiment valour is! (calling from terrace) That's right—launch the boat—never say die! the eyes of your country are on you! I shouldn't mind saving one or two myself, if there was no chance of me becoming food for the fishes! Holloa! there's a poor devil paddling about at the bottom of the terrace ! (throws out rope) All right—he bites! (pulls away at the rope) What a fine thing it is to feel oneself doing a noble action, and saving a fellow creature's life! Steady—steady, my friend—steady!
sp.stage: Ruthven appears outside the terrace, clinging to the rope — Lazare recognises him, and screams out, then pushes him back into the sea.
sp.p: Help! murder! Santa Maria! murder ! (R. corner, on his knees.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: What is the matter? (Lazare making signs, not being able to speak for fright) Speak, Lazare—speak!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: You're lost—I've seen him.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Him! who?

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Bogy—old Nick—my Lord!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Ruthven! Impossible!

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p:
Not at all impossible—I've seen him as I now see
you. I think I ought to know him—I've seen his cadaverous face quite often enough in my dreams. I, like a great ass as I am, wanted to do an heroic action, and save a fellow being's life, and he was the object I fished up—what a bite! But you must be sure, when I saw who it was, I soon pushed him back into the sea. However, no matter—he's sure to come up again. Santa Maria! what will become of us ? I can plainly see all our latter ends before us! (Music)

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: She was right—the dream of happiness has past, indeed ! Leave me ! (throwing himself on chair)

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Most willingly. I only wish I could find a place to hide myself out of his way. I wouldn't mind the bottom of the crater of Vesuvius, only I'm afraid it would be too hot to hold me. I wonder what's the matter with my teeth—they will keep chattering against each other, and won't keep quiet— I'm sure I shall bite off the top of my tongue in a minute. Oh, Santa Maria! where shall I be this time to-morrow ? no doubt a piteously mangled object. Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (starting up) He shall take my life ere he harms her.

div.stage: Music — about to rush off L.— Enter Ziska, R.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Well, Gilbert, spoke I the truth ?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Woman, being, or whatever thou art—for I have of late seen things so strange and incredible, that I have no longer faith in my own reason. Forgive my late folly in disbelieving you—behold me a suppliant at your feet. Save her, and I am yours—your slave for ever. (falls at her feet)

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: At last!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (l.) Let me not see a third virgin fall a victim to his bloody purpose. Shield my affianced bride, and I will bless you for having separated us—only let her live.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (starting up) Where is, then, your boasted power, since you refuse the only boon I ask.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Tis beyond my power to grant it. (clings to him)

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (casting her off) Fiend! avaunt !

div.stage: Music—Enter Antonia, in a bridal dress, L.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: I'm here, dear Gilbert—see my wedding wreath !

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: A funeral one would be more suited now.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: What mean these words, Gilbert—you are pale!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Ay, dear girl, curse me, for I have linked you to my fatal destiny.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: But we will fly if danger menaces. Besides, are you not at my side to protect me ? What, then, have I to fear ?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: But he would seek us in the remotest corner of the universe. Has not this hand thrice laid him low ? Oh, torture! but rather than see you fall a victim to his embrace of death, this hand shall rid this earth of both.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: I know not what you mean, Gilbert—but in life and death I am yours, and yours only.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Heaven bless thee! (they embrace)

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: (upstage) Can they love thus ?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: And now, dearest, let us offer up one last prayer, and then bid farewell to this accursed life for ever ! I have here a deadly poison, which has never quitted me for years.

div.stage: (shows phial —Ziska coming down C., and taking phial from his hand — Music)

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Stay!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: You still here to gloat on our misery !

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Gilbert, judge me not too hastily. Girl, leave us for awhile.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: (crossing c.) Oh, Gilbert, do not send me from you ! (clinging to him)

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: If you would see her saved, bid her leave us!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: But should he—

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I swear, by the love I bear you, she shall be saved !

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Can I trust you ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Can you still doubt me? Bid her go or it will be too late!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Leave us, dearest!

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Oh, Gilbert!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Fear not, Antonia, we can but die together. (Music — Leads her to wing, and kisses her — she exits, L.— Ziska gazes at them, and appears to struggle with her feelings. We are now alone—speak!

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: (R.) You would have died together rather than have lived for me. How willingly would I have changed places with her—But it is past, and I will now show you the extent of the love you have spurned. You shall live and be happy.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (L.) With Antonia?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Ay, with Antonia.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: You can save her ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I can.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Why, then, allow my poor sister to be sacrificed ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I had not then the power I now have.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: What means can be employed to preserve Antonia ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: The only safeguard against the fiend, Ruthven, is to possess an amulet, a cross worn by one of his former victims. Behold it!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: My sister's long lost amulet.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: On the night of her death, I stealthily snatched it from her corse; I took it, thinking I might some day save an innocent virgin, and exterminate Ruthven—I little dreamt it would serve to save my own rival—but not a moment is to be lost. (striking bell on table)
sp.stage: Enter Lazare, R.
sp.p: Run instantly, and place this round Antonia's neck ! (gives amulet.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: On your life lose not an instant.
sp.stage: Lazare staggers off in amazement, L.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: What does all this mean ? (Music)

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Ruthven's term of existence terminates this night at the stroke of twelve. Actuated by a feeling of revenge, he has but sought to make your bride his yearly victim—he waited for you at Tiffanges, feeling sure you would return there ere your wedding. He has followed your steps—and has her now, as he thinks, in his grasp—should he not discover his mistake till too late to seek for another victim, ere the clock strikes midnight, he is exterminated for ever.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Thanks—thanks! Heaven will reward you.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: No, no—I dare not hope it! (staggers to chair)

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: What means this weakness—this pallor ?

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: Can you not guess?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: I will fly for aid.

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: No mortal aid can save me. In giving your bride life I sacrifice my own ? Beings like us are bound by terrible bonds! In giving means to exterminate another, and betraying him, I but condemn myself to everlasting torture. I could have saved her, and yet have not sacrificed myself, had I not divulged who Ruthven was—but then, Gilbert, not knowing the obligation, you would not have cherished my memory as I trust you now will. Besides, I could not exist to see you in another's arms. (falls on ground)

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Oh, Ziska!

sp.speaker: Ziska.
sp.p: I die happy, for I ensure your happiness, although it be with a rival—you, then, can judge if I did not love you! (Gilbert kneels at her feet, and kisses her hand) Thanks—I now willingly part with existence. Farewell earth ! Pardon! Gilbert, pray for me—I dare not!

div.stage: (Music — She gradually expires —Gilbert kneels in prayer. — Closed in by

div.head: Scene Second.— An Antichamber in the Villa.
div.stage: Enter Scopetto and Matteo, L.

sp.speaker: Scopetto.
sp.p: Well, Matteo, but what does all this mean ?

sp.speaker: Matteo.
sp.p: Why, it's strange enough. First, down comes the Signor Lazare, and tells me to shut up all the doors and barricade all the windows, and to fire upon the first person who approached. No sooner had I posted myself in the garden, than a strange sort of gentleman hails me, and says, "Should you like to make your fortune ?" "Of course I should," says I. "Well, then," he says, throwing this purse— (shows one) "find a sturdy arm to help you in carrying off the Lady Antonia, and twice that sum shall be yours." "But my conscience," says I. "Ten purses of gold if you obey, if not, this bullet through your head," says he. At the same moment I felt the muzzle of a pistol tickle my ear. Of course, when a person speaks in such enticing language, it's impossible to mistake his meaning, or refuse him anything, so I told him to get his ten purses of gold ready—and I came after you. Besides, we've not a moment to lose, as he seems in a great hurry.

sp.speaker: Scopetto.
sp.p: But should this young Frenchman, the affianced husband, try to prevent our carrying out our plan!

sp.speaker: Matteo.
sp.p: Why, then, if words won't settle him, our stilettos must.

sp.speaker: Scopetto.
sp.p: Nonsense, man, everything has its price, and ten purses of gold would buy all the consciences in Naples. So come along, and let's gain our money in a business-like way.
sp.stage: Exeunt, L.

div.stage: Enter Gilbert, R.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: I can hardly believe my senses at what has just past. Poor Ziska ! thou hast, indeed, proved thyself a martyr to thy affection—for no sooner had she breathed her last, than her form seemed to melt into air, and left but a shapeless mass of clothing in its place. I will pray for you, poor martyr, and cherish your memory for having saved her whose existence was all to me on earth! (a piercing scream is heard) What was that? Surely she could not have deceived me!
sp.stage: Lazare rushes on, pale and haggard, L.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Oh, oh ! Oh, it's all over with us ! there are more of them now, although I should never have dreamt that they belonged to the sect.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Explain yourself.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p:
Why, no sooner had I done what Ziska told me, and placed that amulet round Ma'amselle Antonia's neck— By
the way, monsieur, did you remark that it was the very amulet that you had so long sought after ?

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Yes—go on !

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: Well, I had no sooner placed it round her neck— now what a sly minx Ziska was, never to tell me that she had it—than in walked those two scoundrels, our two servants, Scopetto and Matteo, whom I'd engaged for their good looks— they knocked me down, took up Ma'amselle Antonia in their arms, and off they bolted with her.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: And you not to prevent them! Follow me! the fiend has not dared show himself. Heaven grant that Ziska has not deceived me! Rushes off, L.

sp.speaker: Lazare.
sp.p: (calling after him) Don't leave me alone. I don't like it—it's past eleven, and nearly twelve o'clock, the hour when vampires walk about. I begin to think the world is half populated with them. I wouldn't stop alone for all the gold in the universe. Here, sir! Sir!
sp.stage: Runs off, L.

div.head: Scene third.
div.stage: —A Churchyard by Moonlight. At back, an Illuminated Chapel. (All the lights down.)
Ruthven discovered C., with the moon full on his face.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Will they come ? If not, I am lost. This feeling of revenge towards Gilbert, to snatch his bride from his arms at the very nuptial hour has made me forget all else. But thanks to fate, she will be mine, and the year I wasted in seeking for her, and her alone, which has endangered my whole existence, will not have been idly spent. The chapel is prepared for Gilbert and Antonia's wedding—in a short time it will be a funeral, and not nuptial service, that will be required.

div.stage: Music —Scopetto and Matteo, L., bring on Antonia in a swoon — they place her on a bank.

sp.speaker: Matteo.
sp.p: Here, signor—you see we've kept our word.

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: (with exultation) Ay, nobly—and there (throws bag of gold) is your reward, and now leave me!

sp.speaker: Scopetto.
sp.p: You mean the young signora no harm, do you? I should be sorry to see her injured, for she's a regular angel!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: (in a voice of thunder) Leave me, I say ! They shrink off alarmed, R.(with exultation) And now, Gilbert, we are quits. Your unknown protector cannot shield her from my fury—she is mine! I shall live to witness his anguish, his despair. Fate, I thank thee!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: (without, L.) Antonia! Antonia!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: His voice ! then not a moment is to be lost!
sp.stage: (Music — He advances towards Antonia to take her in his arms, when he suddenly starts, and seems driven back by a supernatural power)
sp.p: What fiend of hell has done this ? She bears an amulet, which annihilates my power. Who has done this? I am betrayed — she is beyond my reach ! Curse on this infatuated feeling of revenge, which made me neglect my own safety. I will hence-some other victim must be found ere the hour strikes, or I am lost for ever. (about to rush off, L.
sp.stage: Enter Gilbert, L., with a drawn sword, opposing him
sp.p: Let me pass, I say!

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Fiend, repent! for your hour is at hand!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: Never—let me pass! or this moment is your last!

div.stage: (bell begins to strike twelve —Ruthven present pistol, but on hearing the clock, starts —Gilbert takes advantage of this movement, and with his sword, strikes the pistol from his hand — he then rushes on Ruthven, gets him down, and presents sword to his chest — Enter Lazare, L.

sp.speaker: Gilbert.
sp.p: Repent, ere it be too late!

sp.speaker: Ruthven.
sp.p: (struggling for life) Never! Curses on you all! Idiot that I have been! Ziska has betrayed me—but she has paid the forfeit! What forms are these around drawing me back? Mercy! back!

div.stage: (All this is spoken while the clock is striking — on the last stroke of twelve, a thunderbolt strikes Ruthven to the ground — a flame and smoke issue from the earth where he falls, and when it clears off, no signs are seen of him, except a flat mass of rags. Lazare, Gilbert, and Antonia (who has recovered during this, and rushes for protection to Gilbert), shrink back with horror. Music changes. — The chapel disappears, and discovers The Heavens, in which is seen Helene and Juanna, clad in white, with their arms extended towards the Ghoule who, in the act of prayer, is seen gradually ascending towards them. The Tableau is illuminated by celestial rays.
Curtain.
R. L.
